sen.j: 袈裟（けさ）は、仏教の僧が身につける布状の衣装のこと。
sen.e: Kesa is a cloth robe worn by a Buddhist priest
Kesa is a cloth robe worn by a Buddhist priest
Kesa is a cloth robe worn by a Buddhist priest

sen.j: 梵語で「混濁色」を意味するカシャーヤ（Kasaya）を音訳したもの。
sen.e: It is a transliteration of Kasaya of Sanskrit that means "cloudy color."
It is a transliteration of the Sanskrit word Kasaya that means "cloudy color."
It is a transliteration of the Sanskrit word Kasaya that means 'cloudy color.'

sen.j: 糞掃衣（ふんぞうえ）、福田衣（ふくでんね）ともいう。
sen.e: It is also called "funzoe" or "fukudenne."
It is also called "funzoe" or "fukudenne."
It is also called funzoe or fukudenne.
sen.cmt: 原文に『』がないので" "を削除

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 起源は、インドの仏教僧侶が身にまとっていた布。
sen.e: Its origin is a cloth worn by a Buddhist priest.
It was originally a cloth worn by a Buddhist priest.
It was originally a cloth worn by a Buddhist priest in India.

sen.j: 仏教では本来、出家僧侶は財産になるような私有物を持つことを禁じられており、衣服も例外ではなかった。
sen.e: In Buddhism, priests were prohibited to have any private possession that has a value to become property and clothes were not exception.
In Buddhism, priests were prohibited from having any private possessions which could have value; clothes were no exception.
In Buddhism, priests were prohibited from having any private possessions that could have value; clothing were no exception.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: そのため、価値や使い道が無くなり捨てられたぼろ布、汚物を拭う（＝糞掃）くらいしか用の無くなった端布を拾い集め綴り合せて身を覆う布を作った。
sen.e: Therefore, a cloth to cover the body was made by collecting and sewing together rags thrown away after losing its value or use and waste pieces from cutting cloth that can be used only for wiping filth (= funzo (literally, wiping excrement).

Therefore, a cloth to cover the body was made from collecting and sewing together rags which had lost their value, were thrown away, or pieces used to wipe filth (funzo - literally, wiping excrement).

Therefore, a cloth to cover the body was made by collecting and sewing together rags that had lost their value and were thrown away, or something like using pieces of cloth for wiping filth (funzo - literally, wiping excrement).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 布は在家（白い布をまとっていた）と区別するために草木や金属の錆を使って染め直され、黄土色や青黒色をしていた。
sen.e: In order to discriminate with lay believers (wearing white cloth), such cloth was dyed again using plants or rust of metals into ocher or bluish black.
In order to differentiate the monks from lay believers (wearing white cloth), the cloth was dyed again into ocher or bluish black using plants or the rust of metals.
In order to distinguish the monks from lay believers (wearing white cloth), the cloth was dyed again into ocher or bluish black using plants or the rust of metals.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 梵語の名前はこの色に由来する。
sen.e: The name in Sanskrit was originated from this color.
The name in Sanskrit originated from this color.
The name in Sanskrit originated from this color.

sen.j: 作業着にあたる安陀会（あんだえ）、普段着にあたる鬱多羅僧（うったらそう）、儀式・訪問着にあたる僧伽梨（そうぎゃり）の三枚がある。
sen.e: There are three types, that is, andae that corresponds to a working wear, uttaraso that corresponds to an everyday cloth and sogyari that corresponds to a formal or visiting cloth.
There are three types: Andae, which corresponds to working wear, uttaraso that corresponds to an everyday cloth and sogyari that corresponds to a formal or visiting cloth.
There are three types: Andae, which corresponds to working wear, uttaraso that corresponds to an everyday cloth, and sogyari that corresponds to a formal or visit cloth.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: これに食事や托鉢に使う応量器をあわせて、三衣一鉢（さんねいっぱつ）と呼び、僧侶の必需品とされた。
sen.e: Adding oryoki (bowl) that is used for eating and takuhatsu (a traditional form of begging, common to Buddhist monks in Japan), they are called sanneippatsu and deemed as necessary articles for a priest.

Together with oryoki (bowl) which is used for eating and takuhatsu (a traditional form of begging, common to Buddhist monks in Japan), these are known as sanneippatsu and deemed necessary articles for a priest.

Together with bowl that is used for eating and takuhatsu (a traditional form of begging, common to Buddhist monks in Japan), these are known as sanneippatsu and deemed necessary articles for a priest.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 仏教がより寒冷な地方に伝播するにつれて、下衣が着られるようになり、中国に伝わる頃には本来の用途を失って僧侶であることを表す装飾的な衣装となった。
sen.e: In line with dissemination of Buddhism to cooler areas, underwear were used and, when it arrived in China, it had lost its original purpose of use and become decorative clothing to show that the wearer is a priest.

In line with dissemination of Buddhism to cooler areas, underwear was used and, when it arrived in China, it had lost its original purpose for use and become decorative, symbolizing the wearer as a priest.
In accprdance with propagation of Buddhism to cold areas, underwear was used and, when it arrived in China, it had lost its original usage and become decorative, symbolizing the wearer as a priest.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 日本に伝わってからは、さらに様々な色や金襴の布地が用いられるようになり、その組み合わせによって僧侶の位階や特権を表すものになった。
sen.e: After it was brought into Japan, fabrics with various colors or baldachin were used and it became a symbol to show the rank or privilege with its combination.
After it was brought into Japan, fabrics with various colors or baldachin were used and it became a symbol to display rank or privilege in combination.
After it was brought into Japan, cloths with various colors or baldachin were used and it became a symbol of the rank or the privilege of the monk in combination.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 特に江戸時代までは「紫衣（しえ）」、「紫袈裟」は天皇の勅許が必要であった。
sen.e: In particular, up to the Edo period, an imperial permission by the emperor was required for "shie (purple robe for high-ranking priests)" or "murasakikesa (purple kesa)."
In particular, up to the Edo period, permission by the emperor was required to wear "shie (purple robe for high-ranking priests)" or "murasakikesa (purple kesa)."
In particular, until the Edo period, permission by the emperor was required to wear 'shie (purple robe for high-ranking priests)' or 'murasakikesa (purple kesa).'
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: なお、一般の僧は黒い衣であったことから「黒衣」（こくえ）と称された。
sen.e: On the other hand, because priests in general used black clothing, they were called "kokue (black clothing).
On the other hand, because priests in general used black clothing, they came to be called "kokue (black clothing).
On the other hand, because general priests used black clothing, they came to be called 'kokue (black clothing).'
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 形態
sen.e: Forms
Forms
Forms

sen.j: 古くは両肩を含め全身を覆うように着用したが、現在では特別な場合を除き右肩を出すようにして掛ける（＝偏袒右肩（へんだんうけん））。
sen.e: Formerly, a kesa worn to cover the whole body, but, at present, it was hung to reveal the right shoulder excluding special situations (= hendan uken).
sen.cmt: 「偏袒右肩（へんだんうけん）」の定訳不明
sen.e: Formerly, a kesa was worn to cover the whole body, but, at present, it is hung to reveal the right shoulder excluding special situations (= hendan uken).
Formerly, a kesa was worn to cover the whole body, but, at present, it is hung to reveal the right shoulder excluding special situations (hendan uken).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: これは如来が両肩を覆って着用している（＝通肩（つうけん））のに対して、仏への崇拝と畏敬の念を表すためである。
sen.e: This is to show worship and feelings of love and veneration to Buddha in comparison with Nyorai (Tathagata) who wears a kesa to cover both shoulders (= tusked).
This is to show worship and feelings of love and veneration to Buddha in comparison with Nyorai (Tathagata) who wears a kesa to cover both shoulders (= tusked).
This is to show worship and feelings of love and veneration for Buddha in comparison with Nyorai (Tathagata) who wears a kesa to cover both shoulders (tsu ken).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 左肩を隠すのは、仏教では左（手）が不浄とされているためである。
sen.e: The reason why the left shoulder is hidden is that, in Buddhism, the left hand is deemed unclean.
The reason why the left shoulder is hidden is that, in Buddhism, the left hand is deemed unclean.
The reason why the left shoulder is hidden is that the left hand is deemed unclean in Buddhism.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 宗派や用途によって形状に多くのバリエーションがあるが、小さく裁断した布を縫い合わせて作られる基本的な縫製法は共通している。
sen.e: Many variations in form are seen depending on the religious school or use, but the basic sewing method to sew small cut pieces of cloth together is common.
While there are many variations depending on the religious school or use, they still share a common method of sewing together small pieces of cut cloth.
While there are a lot of variations of shape depending on the religious sect or usage, they still share a common method of sewing together small pieces of cloth.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 小さな布を縦に繋いだものを条（じょう）と呼び、これを横に何条か縫い合わせて作られる。
sen.e: A strip of vertically joined small pieces of cloth is called "jo (strip) and kesa is produced by joining multiple jo horizontally.
A strip of vertically joined small pieces of cloth is called "jo (strip) and kesa is produced by joining multiple jo horizontally.
A strip of vertically joined small pieces of cloth is called jo (strip) and kesa is made by joining multiple jo horizontally.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 条の数は一般には五条、七条（しちじょう）、九条（くじょう）の三種類であり、条数の多い方が尊重される。
sen.e: The number of jo is usually five, seven or nine and the more jo, the more worthy it is deems.
The number of jo is usually five, seven or nine and the more jo, the more worthy it is deemed.
The number of jo is usually five, seven or nine; the more jo is used, the more valuable the kesa is deemed.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 古い時代の袈裟には十五条、二十三条なども見られる。
sen.e: In kesa in the former time, kesa with fifteen jo and twenty-three are seen.
In ancient times, kesa with fifteen and twenty-three jo could be seen.
In ancient times, kesa with fifteen or twenty-three jo existed.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 縫い合わされた布が水田のように見えることから、袈裟を福田衣と呼ぶことがある。
sen.e: Because pieces of cloth sewn together looks like paddy fields, it is sometimes called "fukudenne.(literally, lucky paddy field clothing).
Because pieces of cloth sewn together looks like paddy fields, it is sometimes called "fukudenne."(literally, lucky paddy field clothing).
Because pieces of cloth sewn together look like paddy fields, it is sometimes called Fukudenne (lucky paddy field clothing).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 一説には、釈迦に帰依した舎衛国の波斯匿王が仏弟子とバラモン教を見まちがえて礼拝したとされる。
sen.e: According to one view, it was originated from the fact that Hashinoku-o (King Pasenadi) of Sravasti, who became a believer of Shakyamuni worshipped Brahmanism by mistaking for a disciple of the Buddha and asked to make a rule for clothing and Shakyamuni said to Ananda beside him, pointing paddy fields, "How about to make like that."

According to one view, it originated from the fact that Hashinoku-o (King Pasenadi) of Sravasti, who was a believer of Shakyamuni, mistakenly worshipped Brahmanism after mistaking a disciple for that of Buddha.

According to one view, it originated from the fact that Hashinoku-o (King Pasenadi) of Sravasti, who became a follower of Shakyamuni, mistakenly worshipped Brahmanism by mistaking a disciple of the Brahmanism for that of the Buddha.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 区別できるよう衣装の定めを設けるよう願った際、釈迦が傍らの阿難に水田を指差して「あのようにすればよいだろう」と言われたことに由来するという。
sen.e: As a result, he asked that rule be made to govern clothing, so Shakyamuni said to Ananda beside him, pointing paddy fields, "How about making it like that."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: As a result, he asked that a rule be made to govern clothing, so Shakyamuni said to Ananda beside him, pointing the paddy fields, 'How about making it like that.'
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: また、善行の種をまいて功徳を得るとする福田思想に由来するともいう。
sen.e: According to another view, it was originated from concept of Fukuden (the world's unsurpassed Field of Merit) which teach people to gain benefits by doing good deeds.
According to another view, it originated from the concept of Fukuden (the world's unsurpassed Field of Merit) which teaches people to gain benefits by doing good deeds.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置Edited for flow
sen.e: According to another view, it originated from the concept of Fukuden (the world's unsurpassed Field of Merit) that teaches people to gain merit by doing good deeds.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 禅宗では袈裟は嗣法（釈迦以来の仏法が師匠から弟子に正しく伝えられること）の重要な証である。
sen.e: In Zen sect, kesa is the important proof of shiho(the dharma founded by Shakyamuni is inherited by a disciple from a priest master)
In the Zen sect, kesa is important proof of shiho(the dharma founded by Shakyamuni is inherited by a disciple from a priest master)
In the Zen sect, kesa is positive proof of shiho (the dharma founded by Shakyamuni is inherited by a disciple from a priest master).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 師匠は弟子の修行が十分に達成されたと判断した時、仏法の核心を伝授し、その証として祖師伝来の袈裟と持鉢を与える。
sen.e: When the priest master judges that training of the disciple has been successfully completed, he teaches the disciple the core of the dharma and gives a kesa and Jihatsu (nesting set of bowls with which Rinzai unsui (Zen priest in training) eat) which was inherited from the founder of the sect.

When the priest master judges that training of the disciple has been successfully completed, he teaches the disciple the core of the dharma and gives a kesa and Jihatsu (nesting set of bowls with which Rinzai unsui (Zen priest in training) eat) which was inherited from the founder of the sect.

When the priest master judges that training of the disciple has been successfully completed, he teaches the disciple the core of the dharma, and gives the disciple kesa and Jihatsu (nesting set of bowls with which a priest in training eat) that were inherited from the founder of the sect, in proof of the completion.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 「衣鉢を継ぐ」という言葉はこれに由来している。
sen.e: The expression "ihatsu wo tsugu (to assume the mantle of one's master)" are originated from this.
The expression "ihatsu wo tsugu (to assume the mantle of one's master)" originate from this.
The expression 'ihatsu wo tsugu (to assume the responsibilities and duties of one's master)' originates from this.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 一部の宗派では輪袈裟という、簡易型の袈裟を僧侶の他、在家信徒も法会参列時に使用する。
sen.e: In some sects, a simplified-type kesa called wagesa (long-shaped priests' stole) is used by, other than priests, laypersons when taking part in Buddhist mass.
In some sects, a simplified-type kesa called wagesa (long-shaped priests' stole) is used by laypersons when taking part in Buddhist mass.
In some sects, a simplified-type kesa called wagesa is used by laypersons when taking part in a Buddhist mass.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 袈裟雄、袈裟男、今朝男という名前の人をたまに見かける。
sen.e: Occasionally, we meet a person with name of Kesao (袈裟雄, 袈裟男 or 今朝男).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: Occasionally, we meet a person with the name of Kesao (袈裟雄, 袈裟男 or 今朝男).
Occasionally, some persons are named 'Kesao'.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: それは本人の誕生時、胎内で臍帯が首に絡まって生まれてきた状態が、袈裟を着ているように見えることに由来する。
sen.e: It is derived from the fact that the person in question was born with the umbilical cord coiled around his neck in his mothers womb and it looked like wearing a kesa.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: It is derived from the fact that the person in question was born with the umbilical cord coiled around his neck in his mothers womb and looks like the person was wearing kesa.
It is derived from the fact that the person in question was born with the umbilical cord coiled around his neck in his mothers womb and looks like a person wearing wagesa.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 胎内でこの状態になると非常に危険で、死亡率が高くなる。
sen.e: If such condition occurred in the mothers womb, it is very dangerous and the death rate is high.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: Such conditions are very dangerous, and the rate of death among such infants is high.
Such conditions are very dangerous, and the rate of death among such infants is high.

sen.j: 無事生まれてきた子の成長のための呪い事（まじないごと）として、この名がつけられる。
sen.e: Such name is given as incantation for the growth of the baby born safely.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外措置
sen.e: This name is given as an incantation to ensure the growth of a newborn.
This name is given as an incantation to ensure the growth of a newborn.
